an3.50:1.1: “Mendicants, a master thief with three factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.
an3.50:1.3: A master thief relies on uneven ground, on thick cover, and on the powerful.
an3.50:1.4: And how does a master thief rely on uneven ground?
an3.50:1.5: It’s when a master thief relies on inaccessible riverlands or rugged mountains.
an3.50:1.6: That’s how a master thief relies on uneven ground.
an3.50:2.1: And how does a master thief rely on thick cover?
an3.50:2.2: It’s when a master thief relies on thick grass, thick trees, a blind spot, or a large forest grove.
an3.50:2.3: That’s how a master thief relies on thick cover.
an3.50:3.1: And how does a master thief rely on the powerful?
an3.50:3.2: It’s when a master thief relies on rulers or their chief ministers.
an3.50:3.4: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, these rulers or their chief ministers will speak in my defense in the case.’
an3.50:3.6: That’s how a master thief relies on the powerful.
an3.50:3.7: A master thief with these three factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.
an3.50:4.1: In the same way, when a bad mendicant has three factors, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.
an3.50:4.3: A bad mendicant relies on uneven ground, on thick cover, and on the powerful.
an3.50:5.1: And how does a bad mendicant rely on uneven ground?
an3.50:5.2: It’s when a bad mendicant has unethical conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.50:5.3: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on uneven ground.
an3.50:6.1: And how does a bad mendicant rely on thick cover?
an3.50:6.2: It’s when a bad mendicant has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.
an3.50:6.3: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on thick cover.
an3.50:7.1: And how does a bad mendicant rely on the powerful?
an3.50:7.2: It’s when a bad mendicant relies on rulers or their chief ministers.
an3.50:7.4: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, these rulers or their chief ministers will speak in my defense in the case.’
an3.50:7.6: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on the powerful.
an3.50:7.7: When a bad mendicant possesses these three qualities, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.”
